text: The faces of FIVE MEN appear out of a thick cloud of mist rising off a seething lake of boiling water. They look li pale phantoms. Terrified. We HEAR the voice of FATHER CHRISTOVAO FERREIRA. Strong. Resolute.
(reading) "Good Friday, 1633. Pax Christi. Praised be God. Although for us there is little peace in this land now."

Now we see FERREIRA. He is a Jesuit priest. A missionary. the look on his face does not match the reflective tone o voice we are hearing. He is troubled at something he sees turns away... .--but two GUARDS, holding him, force him to look back. V of steam make them seem like creatures in a dream.

(reading) "I never knew Japan when it was a country of light. But I have never known it to be as dark as it is now.” On those last words, Ferreira is pulled, through the stea into close-up. He struggles not to show the pain of what sees.
The five men are surrounded by SAMURAI and various OFFICI Guards are pushing them forward. The five men are THREE AUGUSTINIAN FRIARS, a FRANCISCAN FRIAR and a JAPANESE JES PRIEST.
“All our progress has ended in new persecution, new repression, new suffering. (MORE )

FERREIRA(V.O.) (cont'd) The governor of Nagasaki first hoped to destroy our Christian faith with ridicule, and by example.” Steam from the hot spring ebbs briefly to reveal the men Catholic priests. Their hands are tied. The water in fron them is like a cauldron.

“But when the faithful resisted, and refused to renounce God, he became more cruel." In a grove of trees on a small rise in the near distance, Guards hold tight to the priest Ferreira, making sure he doesn’t miss a thing. They yank Ferreira like a dog on a Closer to the spring.
The five priests tremble at the edge of the scorching spr

"He took four friars and one of our own Society to Unzen. There are hot springs there. The Japanese call them '‘hells,' partly I think in mockery, and partly, I must tell you, in truth." The cold air makes the STEAM rise thickly from the lake.

"The officials told the faithful to abandon God and the gospel of His love. But they not only refused to apostatize. They asked to be tortured, so they could demonstrate the strength of their faith and the presence of God within them." The water throws scalding spray into the air, burning the of one of the priests. Nearby, still guarded by the samurai, Ferreira bites his control himself. His lip bleeds. He watches as... ...the captured priest turns, unbroken, to his captors, refusing to capitulate.

Praise to you, Lord Jesus Christ! (alt: Soul of Christ, sanctify me!) Showing no anger, an Official makes an abrupt gesture. Gu tear off the priests’ garments then dip long-handled ladl into the boiling water of the spring.
Seen now from a distance, as if on a stage: guards approa five Christian prisoners, who are tied nearly naked to wo stakes. The guards DRIP the scalding water onto their bod
"They used ladles filled with holes so the drops would come out slowly, and the pain would be prolonged. Each small splash of the water was like a burning coal." The crowd surges forward.
"Some remained on the mountain for 33 days."
A month later. Still from a distance: The five Christians being untied from the stakes. Their bodies are wracked fr effects of exposure.

“The story of their courage has become almost legend. They give hope to those of us who remain here, against the shogun’s order, to teach the faith. We only grow stronger, in His love.” Near the hot spring, Ferreira collapses to the ground. Hi guard lets him fall. He hides his face in his arms.
TITLE UP: COLLEGE OF MADRE DE DEUS / MACAO / Spring, 1640 hand places a letter on a desk and Father Valignano remov spectacles, reciting the last words of the letter. He kno them well.

Ferreira is lost to us. (looks up) This was his last letter. Valignano is a compelling man, the senior Jesuit superior this mission on the very edge of the known world. He look across at TWO YOUNG PRIESTS, neither older than thirty, w seated before him. One priest, FRANCISCO GARUPE, who has the lean, restless appearance of a hunting animal, looks thoughtful. He is measuring his response... ...-when the second priest speaks. He has an aspect of sp assurance about him, of untested righteousness, but there hungry, haunted look in his eyes, too. He's like a man wh seen his own ghost. His name is SEBASTIAO RODRIGUES.
That was so long ago. It says nothing of him now.
This letter came to us when you were traveling from Portugal. It took years to reach us. It was hidden, smuggled, ransomed and finally put into my hand by a Dutch trader. Who had other news as well.
That he is alive?
That he apostatized. The young priests are stunned.
That he denounced God in public and surrendered the faith and is now living as a Japanese.
That’s not possible. (Father Ferreira risked his life to spread our faith all over Japan. We are here today because of him.)
He was the strongest of us.
He wrote those words during the most sweeping persecution of all. Now things are even worse. Thousands are dead for what we brought them. Thousands more have given up the faith.
You said this trader brought news. But it’s not proven, is it? It could be a slander created to further discredit our faith.
Given the extent of the persecution in that country...
Yes, Father, respectfully. There must be multitudes there who need us too.
(more emphatically now) ...and the fact there has been no other word of him, and the news brought by the Dutchman...
Rumor, Father, only... Rodrigues gestures to Garupe to moderate his tone as Vali fixes him with a look of stern impatience. Garupe lowers head in apology.
..-I must conclude it is true.
If it is true, Father, what would it mean for the Society? For our faith? For all of Catholic Europe? (MORE )
RODRIGUES (cont'd) Father, it seems our mission here is more urgent than ever. We must find Father Ferreira.
I cannot allow that.
But you can’t allow us to abandon our mission.
Your mission was to find word of Ferreira. You have found it. Take this letter with you and return to Portugal.

Excuse me, Father, but the letter relates a terrible history. It says nothing about Ferreira himself. Whatever happened to him is still unknown. All we know of his fate is a slander. Permit me, Father Valignano, but I believe our mission still stands.

location: STEPS OF A GREAT CATHEDRAL DAY 8

text: Valignano walks with the young priests down the steps of cathedral. The great cathedral looms behind them. Fog han the air like clumps of cotton. Outlines of ships in the h can be seen in the distance; occasionally a MAST breaks t the fog, swaying with the roll of the tide, then disappea again.

If I permit you to go on to Japan, I'd be condemning you. This Inquisitor... this Inoue...he is terror itself. He may not be the devil, but he is just as cunning. And he was baptized. (beat) By me, during my ministry. Do you know how many Christians the authorities executed at Shimabara? Thousands. Tens of thousands. Most beheaded.
Each a martyr.
We must honor their memory and ask for their prayers. And we cannot abandon whoever remains. Valignano is wavering, swayed by the passion and idealism the young men. And they know that.
(a beat; then...) No, any missionary work in Japan, of any kind, is now out of the question for us. The only European ships permitted to enter port in Japan are Dutch.
Can the Dutch...
The Dutch are heretics. Religion is just a business advantage to them. No, it is far too dangerous for you.
But how can we neglect a man who nurtured us in the faith? He shaped the world for us. (ALT1: He showed us our calling.) (ALT2: HE formed us as Jesuits.)
And even if this slander should be true, then Father Ferreira is damned.
And we have no choice but to save his soul, Father.
This is in your hearts, then? Both of you?
Yes.
It is. Like our first fervor. (ALT: Like our first fervor we felt in the novitiate. We feel it is a call, Father. )
Then I must trust God has put it there. He calls you to a great trial. From the moment you set foot in that country you step into high danger. (beat) (MORE )
VALIGNANO (cont'd) You will be the last to go, you know. An army of two.
Two to find one. “Satis est, domine, satis est." (Our Saint Francis Xavier’s own words, Father.) “It is enough.”

Rodrigues and Garupe walk briskly past the crowded docks island waterfront. A misty rain falls. Junks are so close moored that their hulls make a scraping, thumping SOUND, muffled cadence. The Europeans take broad strides: the length of their ste their height, makes the Chinese population clogging the s and congregating around the wharves give way before them. CHINESE BUSINESSMAN has to almost trot to keep up.

“May 25, 1640. Pax Christi. God be praised. Father Valignano, as I begin these lines I cannot be sure that, when they are done, they will ever reach you.” The Chinese Businessman bustles ahead of the priests and gestures for them to follow him down a narrow alley.

“But I want to maintain your confidence in our mission, and vindicate your faith in us.” The Chinese Businessman stands at the entrance to a TAVER gesturing for the Priests to step inside. Rodrigues enter first, with Garupe close behind him.
“Today there was wonderful news. Your Mr. Chun got us a boat, with twenty- five Chinese sailors. And he found us a guide. Our first Japanese.”

As the Chinese Businessman hovers in the background, the priests stoop to fit into this dank, low place. Seamen an traders drink steadily at rough tables. Others pass by wi women, who seem to be holding them up as they pass throug shadows. There is a MOAN from the corner of the room.

He is not much. You will see. There is another MOAN. The Chinese Businessman bolts forw and plunges into this heap of shadows... ..+-pulling the body of a MAN (KICHIJIRO) into the feeble The disbelieving priests stare at the heap of humanity ly before them. He is their age, ragged and rough-skinned. CHINESE BUSINESSMAN (cont'd) But after almost two months, he is the only one.
Are you Japanese?
Yes yes. He was drifting on sea. Portuguese bring him.
Are you really Japanese?

Where are you from? Kichijiro crawls back into the comfort of the shadows. Th Chinese Businessman stops him with a kick. Kichijiro turn him, groaning incoherently. The Chinese Businessman takes prudent step back.
Answer them, you fool! These are padres! (no response) Kichijiro! You fool! They will take you home.
Where is your home?
Nagasaki.  10
What’s your work?
He will do what you say.
Fisherman.
Nagasaki is on Kyushu. (Kichijiro eyes him suspiciously) Can you tell us about Kyushu?
You know our language.
Little.
You learned it from the Jesuit padres. You had to. So you are a Christian.
No. No Kirishitan. Kichijiro belches and shrugs.
Good guide for you. And he is Christian too.
(snarls) I am not Kirishitan.
You can tell us.
Kirishitan die. (beat) They die in Nagasaki.

(to Kichijiro) Listen to me. We have money. Help us and we can take you home. We can... Kichijiro abruptly INTERRUPTS Rodrigues, HURLING himself feet of the surprised priests. He grovels, weeping.  11

I want to go home. Not for money. Japan is the country of my family. Please! Take me please! I beg you! Don’t abandon me here! The Chinese Businessman stares at the abject Kichijiro. Rodrigues nods his head slightly in silent assent and Kic immediately prostrates himself in drunken thanks. The Chi Businessman helps Kichijiro up to leave.

You see. He will be very good guide. He will be good. As they make their way out, Kichijiro falls drunk onto a knocking into a man (Chinese? Portuguese?). The man pushe Kichijiro away. Kichijiro tries to stand up when he is pu again (attacked?). He cowers and begs. Rodrigues and Garu react. The Chinese Businessman tries to protect them. Rod and Garupe go to Kichijiro on the floor to stop the viole They help him up and hand him to the Chinese Businessman.
Our guide. He can’t be a Christian.
He says he’s not but can you believe anything he says? The Chinese Businessman takes Kichijiro away down the all the taverners laugh.
I don’t even want to believe he’s Japanese.
(shouting back to priests) You see. He will be good! The priests look at Kichijiro.
"And he said to them: Go ye into the whole world, and preach the gospel to every creature." Even to one such as this.” As the priests watch him, wondering if they'll regret the decision.  11 12 13 12
So our Lord commanded. And as I prepare to do His work, I see His face before me.
Rodrigues lies on his simple bed, staring at the ceiling.
“His face is fresh in my memory. Just as I saw it the first time as a novice in Evora. He looks as he must have when He commanded Peter, ‘Feed my lambs, feed my lambs, feed my sheep.’ ”
CU: The face of Christ in the image that Rodrigues rememb
“It's a face filled with vigor and strength. It fascinates me. I feel such great love for it. ” From the face of Christ, we...

...the face of Valignano, standing on the dock in a misty surreptitiously giving a blessing. A tender boat carrying two priests, now disguised as Chinese sailors, moves towa sea-battered Chinese junk waiting beyond the harbor.

“During the long weeks at sea the gift of God’s trust sustained us both. We never doubted His guiding hand. I embraced this journey as I embraced my vocation, with honest apprehension about my own strength, but with joy, too, that God has trusted me with this chance.”  14 15
16 17 18 13 On the tender, the priests watch the figure of Valignano into the SWIRLING MIST like a daub of paint into a fresco

We have trusted that man with our lives.  19 14

Jesus trusted even worse. And he lowers himself over the side, into the water. Garu hesitates, then follows and they both make for the shore. And now we see where we are. The tender is near the shore Tomogi as the Chinese Junk stays at a distance.

As Garupe and Rodrigues come ashore, Kichijiro GESTURES f them to hurry. They scurry forward toward a hollow rock l animals being pursued by hunters they can only sense. As as they reach shelter, Kichijiro is gone. It startles the

Kichijiro! Kichijiro! He’s gone to betray us. Their fear increases at the SOUND of something moving acr the rocky beach. Footsteps. Drawing closer. They huddle together, caked with soggy sand and dirt, a couple of landlocked sea rats.

“Quod facis, fac citius.” “What you will do, do quickly.” Rodrigues and Garupe press themselves deep in the shadows the rock. Rodrigues is shivering. His teeth are CHATTERIN Garupe reaches for his companion and holds his head again chest, trying to MUFFLE the sound.

(fearfully) "A band of soldiers went there with lanterns and torches and weapons." The priests duck back behind their meager shelter as... ...a LIGHT FLARES suddenly just in front of them. The sound of feet, close now. And VOICES. The priests exc a FRIGHTENED GLANCE, then turn to see... ...the craggy, glowering face of an OLD MAN, looming over His very lack of expression is menacing. He studies them moment. A long, agonizing moment.  15
Padre... The priests are stunned to hear this word in their langua The old man makes the sign of the cross. Tentatively, trembling, Garupe blesses him.
Hurry. There is no time. They SCRAMBLE to their feet as a group of a dozen village carrying torches, surround them.
What is this place?
Tomogi village.
Japan?
(nods agreement) Please. Be quick. So gentios cannot see you.
Gentios? The villagers swarm over the priests, rapidly covering th with field hats and farmers’ overgarments. In their midst Kichijiro smiles at them with servile pride.
(looking at Kichijiro) The way of the Lord surpasses all understanding. With Kichijiro always near, the villagers form a protecti phalanx as they guide them off the beach.

"‘Padre.’ ‘Gentios.’ Our own words sounded so foreign here. But they were a sign that the seed of our faith has been sown, and survives with tenacity. Now it is our mission to tend and nurture it, lest it wither and die.”  20 21 16 ..-Rodrigues and Garupe exchange a look as they are hurri inland.

Now away from the beach, Ichizo deliberately steps off th path and thrashes his way through the woods. The others f The priests stumble, trying to keep up. The going is hard villagers don't give a moment to rest. They press on, har

“We were hurried to shelter because our Christians feared betrayal by those who had not embraced the faith. Gentiles, they called them. Although nearly all the two hundred families of Tomogi had been baptized, many fell under fear of the Inquisitor Inoue.” A villager hands Kichijiro a bottle of local rice wine (nigorizake), from which he takes liberal swigs.

The group comes out of the woods on a plateau just above village. Like haystacks in a rocky field, huts now loom c before them. They move stealthily along this back way tow the village. A man called MOKICHI draws even with them.
Tomogi... our village... I’m sorry Padre, for this way... it is difficult. But too dangerous. There are more executions than ever.
If they know we are Kirishitan we will be killed.
The Lord hears you.
(humbly) Yes. He sent you to us.  22 17 They reach a hut, indistinguishable to the priests from t others dotting the ground. Ichizo nods for them to enter.
INT. ICHIZO’S HUT NIGHT 22 ICHIZO'S WIFE comes out of the shadows and kisses Garupe’ hand, startling him.
We have a little food. If you would like.
Yes, please. Ichizo nods to her, and she leaves.
You'll be safe here until morning.
Thank you. Tell me... (as he looks around) .--how do you live like this? The villagers look at him blankly. He thinks he may have misunderstood. Or, worse, may have insulted them.
I’m sorry, I mean...how do you live as Christians, when the danger is so great?
We pray in secret. But we have our jiisama...
(trying to say the word) Jiis -
Jiisama. He leads us.
Who is this... (struggles with the word) .--Jjiisama? Mokichi NODS at Ichizo, who bows his head modestly.  18
.-+-he leads you? In your devotions?
He prays with us. 22A INT. ICHIZO’S HUT NIGHT 22A On that last word, we CUT AWAY to brief images of Ichizo conducting a baptism.
The only sacrament he can perform is baptism. We worship with the jiisama. We hide the Kirishitan images but God still sees us, yes? Even though we do not have a priest? Until now.

22C INT. ICHIZO’S HUT NIGHT 22C Ichizo's Wife quietly returns and HANDS each of the pries small bowl containing a few scrawny vegetables. They star eat. Mokichi MURMURS A QUICK grace. The priests are surpr And a little embarrassed to have forgotten the blessing. Rodrigues puts his bowl down.
Every Kirishitan here is part of our secret church.The tossama guide us with prayer and teaching. The mideshi help the tossama to preserve the faith.
I would like to meet the tossama.
(nods at Mokichi) It is a group. And Mokichi is one of them. Mokichi lowers his eyes modestly.

There was one of us, a priest, a padre, named Ferreira. Do you know of him?  19 The villagers shake their heads. The priests exchange a q look of disappointment, Suddenly Ichizo's Wife, who has been watching the Western eat, LAUGHS at Garupe’s way with the food. He smiles at h
(smiles, embarrassed) Did I do something wrong? I’m sorry. The expression of puzzlement on his face makes her laugh Rodrigues attempts to smooth over the awkwardness.
All this...this faith you have...this courage...is only in Tomogi? What about other villages? Is it the same?
We do not know about other villages. We never go there.
You don’t go?
Other villages are so dangerous. You don’t know who to trust. Everyone fears the Inquisitor, Inoue Sama.
Anyone can expose you to the men of power. Inform on a Kirishitan and they give you one hundred pieces of silver.
Pieces of silver...
Two hundred for a Kirishitan brother. And, for a priest, three hundred.
(disturbed) Three hundred? I’m flattered.

You should go to the other villages, let them know priests are here again. In Japan again. That would be good. You must let them know.  23 20 Ichizo nods polite agreement, but Rodrigues can see he ha persuaded him. It is as he reaches for his meager bowl of again that he notices Ichizo has not been eating.
(to Ichizo) You do not eat?

It is you who feed us. Rodrigues is struck by the simplicity and force of the an As he bends over his bowl, his NECKLACE WITH A CRUCIFIX ATTACHED SWINGS FREE across his chest. Mokichi sees it. His eyes fill with a flash of emotion an hands make an involuntary movement toward the crucifix. Rodrigues understands. SERIES OF QUICK DISSOLVES: TO the crucifix, pressed to th forehead of Mokichi, who is kneeling before Rodrigues; TO Garupe, offering his own crucifix to Ichizo; TO the old m hands, wrapped around Garupe's; TO Mokichi's hands, as he the cross Rodrigues offers.

(over series of dissolves) “I was overwhelmed right away by the love I felt from these people, even though their faces couldn't show it. They cannot reveal sorrow or joy. Long years of secrecy have made their faces into masks.” Mokichi KISSES the cross and hangs it around his neck.

A SERIES OF FACES in the procession, walking and staring straight ahead. Mokichi. Ichizo. Other villagers. Faces s to be impassive. Garupe and Rodrigues, now dressed entirely in peasant clo are following them with difficulty over the rough terrain Patches of thick wet mist swirl and drift all around them
“They do not dare take us anywhere by the main road. To hide like this must be a terrible burden. (MORE )

24 25 21 RODRIGUES (V.O.) (cont'd) Why do they have to suffer so much? Why did God pick them to bear such a burden? END series of CUs and CUT BACK to the procession...climbi through the woods...seen now from a distance, a ragged or small, brittle figures in an engulfing landscape.
“I pray Garupe and I have the strength to help them.”

A tumbledown charcoal storage hut near the top of the mou The last of the morning mist is just burning off, but the beauty of the landscape only seems to underscore the seve the desolation--of this pathetic shelter.
This is safest here.
If you are found, we will all be killed. When you hear this sound... ..-he makes a WRAPPING SIGNAL on the door.
..-it will be us. If you hear anything else... On the loud OVERLAPPING SOUND of boards being dropped we.
Mokichi and two of the other villagers toss slatted board aside to reveal a deep hole in the ground. Dust and dirt in the air.
Hide.

Konhisan. The young priest looks at her blankly. She begins on her

Another day. Ichizo's hand REACHES for a thin straw mat o floor, RAISES it as if there is something underneath. The nothing. But the hand starts to separate the mat.

“Their old faith offered resignation and a road that ended in darkness. Christianity brought love, and life everlasting. And we see there are two layers of mat, one against the o As Ichizo separates them we see a hidden paper.  23

“The dignity for the first time of being treated like God’s creatures, not animals. And the promise that earthly trial would not end in nothingness, but in salvation.” Ichizo SMOOTHS the wrinkled paper and passes it reverentl Rodrigues, who nods and PASSES it to Garupe. It is a pict Jesus (or Mary). He places it on a low table against the serving as an altar upon which are placed a chalice, pate missal, water and wine. A light has been lit.

“Images of Our Lord and the Blessed Virgin Mary sustain them. So they can see past the image, and find God in their own hearts, we give religious instruction and teach new prayers. Quietly” Rodrigues TURNS: faithful of the village crowd this hut. villagers stare at the picture of Jesus (or Mary) in awe make gestures of great reverence. Rodrigues makes the sig the cross and begins Mass.
In nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti, Amen. Introibo ad altare Dei.... Kichijiro stands in the back, not quite sober, watching.
“We offer Mass in the dead of night, just as they did in the Catacombs. But in whispers. And when morning comes we leave the village...quietly...still with no word of Ferreira.”
Garupe and Rodrigues negotiate the rough path through the forest as Mokichi clears the way just ahead of them.
“,..and we climb the mountain again. And wait. And hide. These people carry the burden of their faith up this steep road more easily than we do. (MORE )

29 24 RODRIGUES (V.O.) (cont'd) Their trust in us is total, and we have to be careful they do not give us too much. When I asked Ichizo's wife for food that first day, she gave us almost all they had. They hurry out of the woods toward the sheltering outline their hut, visible ahead in billowing clouds of early-mor mist.
“The love of all these people overwhelms us both.””
Rodrigues is BAPTIZING a baby held by its mother as the f looks on with a mixture of pride and wariness. He holds t only instrument for the ceremony - a broken little peasan cup used for holy water.
“Paatere to, Hiiriyo to, Supiritsu Santo no mina o motte soregashi nanji o araitatematsuru. Amen.”
We now? All with God, in paraiso?

(frustrated) Paradise? Now? No. But God is there now, and forever. He prepares a place for us all. Even now. The husband and wife give no sign of comprehending, but t bow and leave, passing Ichizo's Wife standing patiently h two meager bowls of food.
Blessed be God. (beat) Arigataya. She BOWS and exits. Garupe HANDS Rodrigues a bowl of food
I'm sorry, Sebastiado, for my impatience. I’m ashamed of my frustration.  30 25 Rodrigues NODS his head in understanding.
The child is safe in God's grace. That's what’s important. Both priests bow their heads over the food in silent bles then start to eat.

“Joy of my heart.”

The only way we can win against these things is to get out of here. Rodrigues tweezes several small white lice with his finge Frustrated, Garupe picks up a rock and pounds at them. GARUPE (cont'd) (pummeling the lice) I'm sorry. I know that's weak. (WHACK! )
But all I feel for these people is pity, not love.
I know. I feel pity too. (beat) Our Saint Francis also told us to render an account first to God, then to our own conscience. Then we can do much good for our neighbors.  26
Do you think we have? Done good?
Yes I do. Of course I do.
Much good? Rodrigues wipes his hands and passes Garupe a small bowl roots and pumpkin scraps.
It's just that these people are so frightened. Is fear all they have? (WHACK! )
And lice?
They have us. We comfort them.
How much longer can we do that?
We asked for this mission, Francisco. We begged Father Valignano for it. We prayed for it in the Exercises. God heard us then, He hears us still.
Then may He guide us to Ferreira. So we can know the truth.
The truth.
Do you think there’s any doubt?
About what?
You think his strength gave out and he groveled in front of the Inquisitor Inoue? Went on his knees like a dog?  31 27
That’s still just a rumor. Even if this Inoue is the devil everyone claims, Ferreira would stand up to him.
You don’t seem so certain, Francisco. (no reply from Garupe) One of us has to go to Nagasaki and find him.
It’s too dangerous. If we’re caught there will be terrible reprisals to the people who shelter us.
Then Kichijiro can go and bring back word we can act on.
Are you mad? Where is he? Kichijiro’s never sober. You know he can’t be trusted.
So we stay here like this? No. We must do something to find Father Ferreira. Garupe bangs his food bowl down on another swarm of lice.
Yes. Of course. But first I have to find all these lice. The SOUND of the rock echoes through the hut as Garupe continues to attack the lice.
A few hours later. Beams of straggling SUNLIGHT creep ben the door.
